Award.AwardTitle: Operator Algebras, Groups, and Applications to Quantum Information
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the thematic research program Operator Algebras, Groups, and Applications to Quantum Information that will be held from March 11 to June 29, 2019, at the research institute ICMAT in Madrid, Spain. The conference focuses on recent developments in the field of operator algebras (C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras) and its interactions with group theory and the relatively young subject of quantum information. The main activities of the program consist of two schools, two workshops, and an international conference, and the themes to be addressed include classification aspects of C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras, the dichotomy between amenability and paradoxicality in its various guises, and the Connes embedding problem in relation to quantum information.

A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak in the schools, workshops, and international conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, and researchers not funded by NSF an opportunity to participate in this program. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities.
More information is available at:

https://www.icmat.es/RT/2019/OAGAQI/activities.php

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The spring 2019 thematic research program "Operator Algebras, Groups and Applications to Quantum Information'' at the Institute of Mathematical Sciences (ICMAT) in Madrid, Spain, provided a venue for collaboration between mathematicians and mathematical physicists working on various topics in and around operator algebras and quantum information theory, while also offering a variety of resources for graduate students and early career investigators to identify promising directions of research and to advance and disseminate their work. The formal activities included two schools, two workshops, and a capstone conference, and there was a total of approximately 135 participants. Contact with researchers from several different countries afforded the US delegation a valuable opportunity to establish and strengthen international scientific networks in fields that have long traditions on both sides of the Atlantic. The program was highly interdisciplinary and covered topics ranging from classification problems in C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras to connections between operator algebras, groups, and dynamics and mathematical aspects of quantum information theory. The significance and timeliness of the latter is reflected in the very recently announced solution to Connes's embedding problem, which is sure to further intensify activity at the intersections between quantum information theory, the structure theory of operator algebras, and geometric and combinatorial group theory that the thematic research program was designed to promote.
